1 .  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Sealed Air Corporation (SAC) Holyoke facility  has many policies and procedures to ensure the safe operation of its facilities. Some of these include the written operating procedures describing how to execute a task safely, training employees on the procedures that are needed to perform their jobs, training employees how to respond to emergencies, and empowering employees to shut down activities that they believe are unsafe.  In addition, the Holyoke facility has implemented an accidental release prevention policy which integrated containment technologies, redundant safety systems, operating/emergency procedures and management processed.  The applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) are adhered to. 

 

2 .  The Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled.

SAC - Holyoke facility manufactures light weight foam packaging used in the consumer industry.  The plant uses propane as a blowing agent to make plastic foam.  This is the only regulated substance in threshold quantities at this location.  Propane (CAS 74-98-6) is a flammable aliphatic hydrocarbon similar to gasoline.  Propose is used and stored as a liquid, but is released (slowly out gassed) from the product during the manufacturing process.



3.  The Worst and Alternative Case Scenarios.

The worst case release scenario as defined by EPA assumes out storage tank completely fails, all safety systems fail, worst-case weather conditions exist, the vapors find an ignition source and released forms a gas explosion.  The endpoint is 1psi overpressure is 0.3 miles.  The alternative release scenario is more credible scenario based on an analysis of potential hazards at our facility.  Maximum release of pounds from a catastrophic failure of the delivery piping system.  The impact distances is based on maximum distance at which the radiant heat affects of a vapor cloud fire might have serious consequences, >.1

miles or in most cases, within our property lines.  The impact distance in both cases has been derived from the EPA RMP Comp to perform offsite consequence analysis required under the EPA's RMP rule.



4.  The Worst and Alternative Case Scenarios.

The worst case release scenario as defined by EPA assumes out storage tank completely fails, all safety systems fail, worst-case weather conditions exist, the vapors find an ignition source and released forms a gas explosion.  The endpoint is 1psi overpressure is 0.3 miles.  The alternative release scenario is more credible scenario based on an analysis of potential hazards at our facility.  Maximum release is approximately 4280 pounds from a catastrophic failure of the delivery piping system.  The impact distances is based on maximum distance at which the radiant heat affects of a vapor cloud fire might have serious consequences, >.1 miles or in most cases, within our property lines.  The impact distance in both cases has been derived from the EPA RMP Comp to perform offsite consequence analysis required under the EPA's RMP rule.



5. Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

?Documented information pertaining to the equipment, technology, and chemicals used in the process

?Written operating procedures and training for start-up, normal operations, emergency operations, operating limits, and consequences of deviation.

?Early detection systems that include high level alarms and interlocks.

?Mitigation systems that include tank pressure relief, gas monitoring system, fire suppression systems, etc.

?Documented employee training on all operating procedures and safety policies and procedures.

?Comprehensive Mechanical Integrity Program

?Management of Change/Pre-startup Safety Review Procedure

?Incident Investigation Procedure

?Hot Work Permit Procedure

?Employee Participation Guideline

?Contractor Program

?Compliance Audit Schedule



6.  Emergency Response Program:

The SAC-Holyoke Plant works closely with the local fire department  including sharing of pre-plans, training, and coordination of drills. SAC- Holyoke employees and contractors receive training on the Emergency Response Plan for initial assignment, and or when their responsibilities with respect to the Plan are changed; and or whenever the Emergency Response Plan is revised. Additionally, employees are also involved in facility drills to test the emergency capabilities and response.
